Instruction: Consider the effect of treatment on the treated (ETT) of whether a person has diabetes on whether a person eats a balanced diet.
Question: For those with whether a person has diabetes being diabetic, if their whether a person has diabetes had been non-diabetic, would the whether a person eats a balanced diet have been more likely to be unbalanced?

given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Whether a person exercises regularly has a direct effect on whether a person has difficulty breathing. Whether a person eats a balanced diet has a direct effect on whether a person requires medical treatment. Whether a person has high blood pressure has a direct effect on whether a person requires medical treatment. Whether a person has diabetes has a direct effect on whether a person requires medical treatment. Whether a person smokes has a direct effect on whether a person has lung cancer. Whether a person smokes has a direct effect on whether a person has respiratory issues. Whether a person has lung cancer has a direct effect on whether a person has respiratory issues. Whether a person has lung cancer has a direct effect on whether a person has difficulty breathing. Whether a person has respiratory issues has a direct effect on whether a person requires medical treatment. Whether a person has difficulty breathing has a direct effect on whether a person requires medical treatment.

Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 9 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and 10 edges A->H, B->I, C->I, D->I, E->F, E->G, F->G, F->H, G->I, H->I.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents whether a person exercises regularly, B represents whether a person eats a balanced diet, C represents whether a person has high blood pressure, D represents whether a person has diabetes, E represents whether a person smokes, F represents whether a person has lung cancer, G represents whether a person has respiratory issues, H represents whether a person has difficulty breathing and I represents whether a person requires medical treatment.

Instruction: Consider the effect of treatment on the treated (ETT) of whether a person has high blood pressure on whether a person has lung cancer.
Question: For those with whether a person has high blood pressure being normal, if their whether a person has high blood pressure had been high, would the whether a person has lung cancer have been more likely to be positive?
